2f987eb548caf12a20b1f82932f24a04 (10:36): Jicksta, ; In closing, a non unsigned INT is 10 chars long. By saying INT(11) it times that by 254 you said? I'm just trying to remember it in my head
0121a3be779bf2eb7d12af9908c7aab8 (10:36): newbieme: i dont remember how, but i believe there is a way, the manual says something about it somewhere
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:36): right. the range of one byte is 0 - 254
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:36): so if you have two bytes, you have 255*255
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:36): it makes sense
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:37): think of it on the order of powers of 2
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:37): with one bit, the range is 2^0
2f987eb548caf12a20b1f82932f24a04 (10:37): i got it. I was just confused. I like to figure out why it was working before I just changed it
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:37): two bits, 2^1
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:37): keep adding bits and the range increases by a factor of two
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:38): since 2^8 = 255, adding another byte would be 255*255
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:39): anyway, I hope you're set now roler
2f987eb548caf12a20b1f82932f24a04 (10:39): I am, thank you!
6eb0ef4e26c6577e69fd762ebe9c25b9 (10:39): it's 12:38 a.m. here and I'm still at work  :)
